docs.snippet: 9 P.M. (13, 49) JEROME ROBBINS: SOMETHING TO DANCE ABOUT Robbins, left, redefined dance and musical theater through his choreography for Broadway shows like ''West Side Story,'' ''Gypsy'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and his works for American Ball...
docs.lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (13, 49) JEROME ROBBINS: SOMETHING TO DANCE ABOUT Robbins, left, redefined dance and musical theater through his choreography for Broadway shows like ''West Side Story,'' ''Gypsy'' and ''Fiddler on the Roof'' and his works for American Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet. But he was also contradictory and controversial, noted for unforgiving perfectionism and haunted by his decision in 1953 to name names in his testimony before the House Un-American Activities Committee. This ''American Masters'' documentary features excerpts from Robbins's work and rare rehearsal footage, as well as interviews with his colleagues Mikhail Baryshnikov, Jacques d'Amboise, Suzanne Farrell, Arthur Laurents, Peter Martins, Chita Rivera, Stephen Sondheim, Jerry Bock, Sheldon Harnick and Joseph Stein. 7 A.M. (NBC) TODAYSteve Harvey discusses his new book, ''Act Like a Lady, Think Like a Man.'' In another segment, real-life shopaholics confess.

docs.snippet: FAIRCHILD--Robert F. of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerso...
docs.lead_paragraph: FAIRCHILD--Robert F. of New York and Quogue died suddenly on February 16th, after enjoying a wonderful weekend fishing on his boat, The Grand Cru. Beloved father of Stephanie and Roger Griswold, Suzie and Bruce Kovner, Samantha and Chris Storkerson, Serena and Tyler Sheldon; cherished grandfather of Caroline, Olivia, Liam, Oscar, Roger, and Margaux. Born and raised in New York City, Bob graduated from the University of Pennsylvania and went to work for the family's firm, Fairchild Publications. Bob joined The House of Burgundy in 1971, and is the President and Chief Executive Officer. In May of 1994, he founded the Maison des Grands Crus, in Santenay, France. On July 16, 1987 in recognition of his efforts on behalf of French wines, Bob was made a Chevalier of the Ordre du Merite Agicole, by the French Parliament. Bob is a member of the Board of Overseers of the University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine, and the Board of Trustees of the Avon Old Farms School. A former member of the Board of Governors of the Union League Club of New York, he also belongs to the Leash Club of New York, Bath and Tennis Club of Palm Beach, Quogue Field Club and Quogue Beach Club and the Long Island Wyandanch Club. Family will receive friends on Thursday, 7-9pm and Friday 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st Street. Funeral service will be held on Saturday at 10:30am at St. Thomas More, 89th Street (between Madison and Park Avenues). In lie of flowers, please make donations to The University of Pennsylvania School of Veterinary Medicine of Avon Old Farms School.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  FAIRCHILD, ROBERT F

docs.snippet: The Bagger, a Continental loyalist and a Newark habitué, snuck across to J.F.K. this morning and hopped on Virgin America to LAX. It's partly because he felt compelled to come out to L.A. a few days early and Continental demanded custody of his f...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Bagger, a Continental loyalist and a Newark habitué, snuck across to J.F.K. this morning and hopped on Virgin America to LAX. It's partly because he felt compelled to come out to L.A. a few days early and Continental demanded custody of his first- and second- born in return for the change. And besides, he's doing a story involving Richard Branson and he had to experience his airline somewhere along the way.
docs.abstract: The Bagger, a Continental loyalist and a Newark habitué, snuck across to J.F.K. this morning and hopped on Virgin America to LAX. It's partly because he felt compelled to come out to L.A. a few days early and Continental demanded custody of his first- and second- born in return for the change.

headline.main: The Bagger Over America: Looking at Things From 30,000 Feet

docs.snippet: The trailer opens with a pan of the New York City skyline before moving on to a cabdriver getting out his vehicle looking up at the sky like he's just seen a U.F.O. In a dizzying rush the scene moves to Paris and a man sitting at an outdoor cafe, ...
docs.lead_paragraph: John Singleton's heavily hyped trailer for the 81st Academy Awards was finally released in 11,000 theaters around the country on Friday, and has made its way to YouTube. Sid Ganis, the president of Academy, described it as "a powerful spot that will whet movie lovers appetites for a terrific show." But if those movies lovers are anything like us, they may end scratching their heads.
docs.abstract: The trailer opens with a pan of the New York City skyline before moving on to a cabdriver getting out his vehicle looking up at the sky like he's just seen a U.F.O. In a dizzying rush the scene moves to Paris and a man sitting at an outdoor cafe, the Eiffel Tower in the background. Zoom! Then we're on an ocean coastline and finally in space.

docs.snippet: We're smack in the middle of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week and if your head isn't hurting yet, you haven't been paying attention. Fortunately, a elite corps of critics are on the job, and so are we. Today, Scorecard has compiled sound bites from the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: We're smack in the middle of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week and if your head isn't hurting yet, you haven't been paying attention. Fortunately, a elite corps of critics are on the job, and so are we. Today, Scorecard has compiled sound bites from the reviews of Abaeté, ADAM, Alexander Wang, Barbara Tfank, BCBG Max Azria, Bibhu Mohapatra, Charlotte Ronson, Christian Cota, Costello Tagliapietra, Cushnie et Ochs, Davidelfin, Elise Overland, Jason Wu, Jenni Kayne, Karen Walker, Koi Suwannagate, Lacoste, Lyn Devon, Monique Lhuillier, Nicole Miller, Ohne Titel, Prabal Gurung, Rachel Comey, Rachel Roy, Rag & Bone, Ruffian, Shipley & Halmos, Stærk, Threeasfour, TSE, United Bamboo, Vena Cava, VPL and Yigal Azrouël. Which Nepalese newbie was feeling the critics' love, and which CFDA/Vogue Fund winner wasn't? Find out below..
docs.abstract: We're smack in the middle of Mercedes-Benz Fashion Week and if your head isn't hurting yet, you haven't been paying attention. Fortunately, a elite corps of critics are on the job, and so are we. Today, Scorecard has compiled sound bites from the reviews of Abaeté, ADAM, Alexander Wang, Barbara Tfank, BCBG Max Azria, Bibhu Mohapatra, Charlotte Ronson, Christian Cota, Costello Tagliapietra, Cushnie et Ochs, Davidelfin, Elise Overland, Jason Wu, Jenni Kayne, Karen Walker, Koi Suwannagate, Lacoste, Lyn Devon, Monique Lhuillier, Nicole Miller, Ohne Titel, Prabal Gurung, Rachel Comey, Rachel Roy, Rag & Bone, Ruffian, Shipley & Halmos, Stærk, Threeasfour, TSE, United Bamboo, Vena Cava, VPL and Yigal Azrouël. Which Nepalese newbie was feeling the critics' love, and which CFDA/Vogue Fund winner wasn't? Find out below..Prabal GurungDesigner: Prabal GurungDate and Location: Thursday, Feb. 12, 6 p.m., Flag Art Foundation, 545 West 25th StreetPhotos: slide show " 'Saint Laurent was all I knew in Nepal,' Mr. Gurung said. That sounds like a title for a short story. It would go something like: New designer cuts through muddle and makes good sophisticated clothes." (The New York Times) "made a bold statement in black, white, and red . . . [and] were also unabashedly luxe, with such extravagances as double-faced cashmere, hand-sewn feathers and embroideries done in India. But Gurung, who explained that dresses will retail for around $2,200, is unbowed. 'I just want to do beautiful, well-made clothes,' he said. Godspeed." (style.com) "[Gurung's] clothes seem suited perfectly to chic grown-ups" (WWD) Alexander WangDesigner: Alexander WangDate and Location: Saturday, Feb. 14, Roseland Ballroom, 239 West 52nd StreetPhotos: slide show "a show with strong attitude, even if the 1980s influence seemed too prevalent.  . . . Wang's designs brought back the power woman in all her feline glory." (The International Herald Tribune) "Learning that a discoing sex appeal has returned to the runways is a little like hearing that Barbra Streisand and Barry Gibb are reuniting. Oh, really? Alexander Wang's collection of black biker shorts, bodysuits and motorcycle jackets with foxtail fringe -- spotlighted at the Roseland Ballroom and set to the beat of 'Thriller' -- was surprisingly old-hat." (The New York Times) "Walking into the big ballroom -- as packs of photographers flashed It chicks Jen Brill and Sophia Hesketh, and even some bona fide celebrities (Sarah Jessica Parker and Zoe Kravitz) -- it felt like  . . . 2008." (style.com) "If a girl wants rocker fierceness with loads of skin-baring, flying fur and biker shorts galore, then Wang's her guy" (WWD)

headline.main: Scorecard | Alexander Wang, Lacoste, Et Al.

docs.snippet: For those of you "Rachel Getting Married" diehards, it's looking more and more like Film Independent's Spirit Awards the day before the Oscars are your only real shot for some hardware....
docs.lead_paragraph: For those of you "Rachel Getting Married" diehards, it's looking more and more like Film Independent's Spirit Awards the day before the Oscars are your only real shot for some hardware. Just recently, the Film Next did a bit of a backstage deconstruction on the Spirits that managed to shed some light on the event without obliterating its substantial charms.
docs.abstract: For those of you "Rachel Getting Married" diehards, it's looking more and more like Film Independent's Spirit Awards the day before the Oscars are your only real shot for some hardware.

docs.snippet: "Slumdog Millionaire" may be a catalyst for a prime-time comeback for "Millionaire" on ABC....
docs.lead_paragraph: The Oscar contender "Slumdog Millionaire" acts as a big-screen reminder of one of the biggest television hits of the past decade, "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire." The film may also be a catalyst for a prime-time comeback for "Millionaire" on ABC, Brian Stelter reports in Saturday's New York Times:
docs.abstract: "Slumdog Millionaire" may be a catalyst for a prime-time comeback for "Millionaire" on ABC.

headline.main: Will ABC Mount a Revival of 'Millionaire?'

docs.snippet: Suggest a question for the Carpetbagger to pose to a famous person at the Oscars and you could win a prize....
docs.lead_paragraph: Why our colleague The Carpetbagger is still allowed near famous people (particularly after this interaction with Angelina Jolie), we’ll never know. Nonetheless, he will be one of the bona fide journalists working the red carpet at the Oscars on Sunday, and he’s looking for your suggestions and input. If the idea of the Bagger posing your question to, say, Mickey Rourke or Robert Downey Jr. isn’t reward enough, there are more tangible benefits for participating:
docs.abstract: Suggest a question for the Carpetbagger to pose to a famous person at the Oscars and you could win a prize.
